div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, MAY 2, 1907.

div.head: Zagazig Races.
div.p: The entries for the Zagazig races will close on Saturday.

div.head: Victoria College.
div.p: The Victoria College's annual athletic sports will be held on the College grounds on Thursday next, the 9th inst. The first event will begin at 2 pm.

div.head: Wreck at Ras Dabba.
div.p: The schooner, chartered by the Coastguard Administration to take tiles to Dabba for the new Coastguard station being built there is a complete wreck. She is lying close to the shore and has fallen over on her side. There is very little chance of saving the tiles.

div.head: Attack on a Poet.
div.p: The attack on the Syrian poet, Chekri Ganem, at the Cafe Chicha in Cairo, has aroused considerable interket. The aggressor, M. Lechat, has been arrested by the French Consulate and was examined in Tuesday, The condition of M. Ganem is serious.

div.head: Coastguard Administration.
div.p: It has been decided to attach the cruiser “Abbas” to the training ship ‘“Daeb-el-Bahr” for educating cadets and training marine recruits, This is a good measure as owing to the number of cruises on which the “Abbas? goes, the recruits and cadets get a good prac- tical training in seamanship.

div.head: Khedivial Mail Line.
div.p: The Khedivial Mail 8.8. “ Osmanieh ” will resume the express service on the 9th inst. working the new express itinerary from Alex- andria ta Constantinople via Piraeus. Leaving here on Thursday the “ Osmanieh ” is due to arrive at Constantinople on Saturday, a vo- yage which will constitute a record.

div.head: Alt Saints Church, Ramleh.
div.p: The Rev. A. H. Ellaby, who has been acting as temporary Chaplain for the past six months, left on Tuesday en route for England, and the Rev. E. H. Blyth who has been appointed permanent chaplain arrived and assumed charge Yesterday. Mr. Blyth’s address for the present will be Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.

div.head: Court of Cassation.
div.p: The work of the cassation eourt shows a considerable decrease, the number of criminal pourvois, received by the Parquet in 1906 being 1,084 as against 1,356 in 1905, and 838 correc- tional against 1,000. The proportion of success- ful pourvois in correctional cases was 4.76%, but incriminal cases out of 99+ cases disposed of only 8 applications were successful, these cases being sent back for retrial.

div.head: Khedivial Decorations.
div.p: The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Major and Brevet-Colonel Lord Edward Herbert Cecil, D.S,0. his Majesty’s Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Second Class of the, Imperial Ottoman Order of the, Osmanieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorized by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by him.

div.head: Anglo-American Hospital.
div.p: We are requested to state that the number of tickets sold for the Anglo-American Hospital ball was 941, the net profits available for the hospital amounting to L.E. 610. The com- mittee wish to express their great gratitude to all who kindly assisted, and especially to the ladies Committee, whose labours contributed so largely to the suecess of the ball. Their thanks are also due to the management of the Gezireh Palace Hotel for tie satisfactory manner, in which all the arrangements were carried out.

div.head: Khedivial Mail Liner Ashore.
div.p: Writing under date of the 30th ult, onr Suez correspondent reports that the Khedivial mail liner Keneh, is reported to be ashore 17 miles. South of Massawah. In Italian gunboat from Massawah has gone to her assistance, as well as the corhpany’s steamer Missir, which sailed from here on the 29th and the Mahallah which left Aden on the 28th, The Missir carried salvage gear and pumps and is due at the steamer on Saturday morning, when the Khediviel Mail Steamship and Graving Docks Co, Ltd. hope the vessel will be easily floated.

div.head: Anti-Tuberculosis League.
div.p: The féte organised by the committee of the Anti-Tuberculosis League for the construction of a tuberculosis hospital at Alexandria, has been definitely fixed for Sunday the 12th inst, at San Stefano Casino, Several ladies have kindly consented to assist at this charity fite and these met yesterday under the presi- dency of Mrs. Chataway to draw up the programme, which includes military bands and orchestra, lottery sales, cinematograph, photography, various games, buffets, rifle shoot- ing, etc. etc., and, be it noted, the pick of Alexandria’s youth and beauty will take charge of the lottery counters and refreshment stalls.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S DEPARTURE
THE NATIONAL MEMORIAL.
div.p: A meeting of the leading residents of Alex- andria was held yesterday afternoon at five o'clock at the Alexandria Municipality to consider the report of the committee, who had visited Cairo to consult with the committee formed in the Capital as to the most fitting way in which Lord Cromer's work should be perpetuated by a public memorial. Messrs Padoa Bey and Salvago, werd deputed to consult with the Cairo committée and it was at the joint meeting decided that a tuberculo- sis hospital shduld be erected, and that a commission of doctors should be appointed to decide whether Cairo or Alexandria afford- ed the midst favourable site for sach an institu- tion. After a lengthy discussion in which Messrs. Sinadino, Baron Jacques dé Menasce, Padoa' Bey, Salvago, Foster, ‘Schiess Pasha, Chataway, Kenderl, Benachi, Luigi, Stagni, Romano, A. Hari, and Dr. Valensin took part, it was decided to found a tuberculosis hospital at Alexandria. It was also resolved that every town of importance and Cairo in particular should be provided with a similar institution for local needs.

The following ordre du Jour was then voted upon and carried :-— Le Comité général désirasit donner a la souscription ane importance en rapport avec Vhommage général a rendre a S. S. Lord Cromer, excluant l‘idée de concentrer’les tuberculeax de toute l'Egypte a Alexandrie, persistant dans son projet de créer un asile pour le seul be- soin de la villé, décide de joindre la sons- cription a celle du,reste de l’Egypte, réservant sau comité du Caire le surplus des sommes souscrites a Alexandrie pour I’asile a créer dans cette ville.”

Dr. Schiess Pasha was then asked by the meeting to open general subscription lists and. to distribute the lists with the assistance of two members; these lists will be published in the local newspapers. We have received the following official notice :—

The subscription list for the Lord Cromer Tuberculosis Hospital is open from to-day. Subscriptions will be received by the general secretary of the committee, Mr. Chataway, at the Municipality. Lord Cromer will leave Cairo at 11 am, on Monday. A guard of honour of British troops will receive his Lordship at Bab-el-Hadid station and troops will also be stationed along the route from the Agency. On Tuesday the members of the Diplomatic Corps presented Lord Cromer with a silver service engraved with his Lordship’s name and a letter signed by the representatives of all the Powers. After the presentation had been made a photograph of the Diplomatic Corps grouped round Lord Cromer was taken.
THE CAIRO DEMONSTRATION.

Tickets for residents in Alexandria invited to attend the demonstration at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, in honour of Lord Cromer have been distributed by the Gouvernorat. The midday, express to Cairo will arrive in time for the ceremony, and those taking part in it can return by a special train to leave Cairo at 8 p.m.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Algerian sailed last Friday evening for Liverpool direct with a general cargo including 1406 bales of cotton and 16772 bags of onions.
The Moss liner Amasis sailed on Tuesday afternoon for Liverpool via Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 19,341 bags onions.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Khios sailed last evening for Liverpool via Malta and Algiers with passengers and a general cargo including 634 bales of cotton and 17,393 bags of onions.
The S.S. City of Dundee of the Westcott and Laurance line left Malta on Tuesday, and is due here next Monday, with general cargo from Antwerp and London and sheep from Tripoli of Barbary.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd’hui a midi et demie).
Les affaires sont rares et la corbeille est déserté par les courtiers qui sont occupés aux réglements fin de mois.
La liquidation au Caire et a Alexandrie s'est effectuce aisément et sans encombre,

De fortes ventes de titres égyptiens faites pdur le compte de notre place sur les marchés étrangers ont largement contribué a alléger un grand nombre de positions surchargées. On évalue a plus de 3,000 le nombre d’actions de la National Bank veridues a Londres a la suite de certains ordres donndés per notre ville.

Il y a tout liéu decroire que les cours de compensation seront maintenus au dela du 10 Mai courant. La situation s'est neanmoins considérable- ment assainie et une reprise parait probable avant la saison prochaine.

div.head: JUDICIAL ADVISER'S REPORT.
CRIMINAL JURISDICTION. (CONTINUED)
div.p: In our last issue we reviewed that portion of Sir Malcolm McIlwraith’s Report dealing with judicial statistics and civil jurisdiction in the native tribunals, and we now turn our attention to the chapter on criminal jurisdiction in the same tribunals. This is dealt with under seven headings as follows: (a) criminal inquiries, (b) markaz tribunal, (c) summary tribunals) (d) central tribunals, (e) assize courts, (f) court of appeal, (g) cassation.
CRIMINAL INQUIRIES.

The institution of markaz tribunals has afforded considerable relief to the Parquet, as prior to this the arrears of cases undispoaed of had been steadily increasing. The figdres at the end of 1906 represent some seven days’ oases in the hands of the Parquet, and some 2 to 3 days cases only in the hands of the markas officers. It is somewhat remarkable that of the 64,457 complaints finally adjudicated upon by the Parquet 15,382 (23.57) wore filed as oither unfounded or as disclosing no offence, or as being of insufficient importance to proseonte, and in the markazes 16.7 % of the oases were 30 disposed of. Of the 47,871 real offences regarded by the Parquet, 5,586 were classified as crimes, 32,810 as misdemeanours, and 10,975 as contraventions. No useful compari- son of the number of real crimes can be made between 1906 and previous years, as the system of classification has been entirely altered. After making the corrections necessary for comparison, however, it appears that the number of real crimes: for 1906 was 3,201 against 3,011 in 1905, 80 that the tendency is to increase in a moderate degree ; as the Adviser points out in a foot note, this seems to be the tendency in England also.
MARKAZ TRIBUNALS

The number of misdemeanours tried by these tribunals in 1906 was 30,736, a decrease of 11,142 on the figures for 1905. Contraventions also show a decrease, the figures being 69,881 as compared with 85,476, and the number of cases remaining on hand at the end of the year showed a diminution of 33 %. In misdemeanours 7% of the cases were ac- quitted and in contraventions 54%. In mis- demeanours 29,26 7% of the convictions resulted in sentences to imprisonment and 14% in contraventions.
SUMMARY COURTS.

The proportion of misdemeanours (based on the figures for all such cases, whether talling within the jurisdiction of markaz courts or not) kept by the markazes shows a decrease of 54% over 1905, but if only the offences. where the markaz and summary courts. have con- current jurisdiction are reckoned, the propor- tion kept by the former is much greater: to take two examples—92% of the assault cases, and 86% of resistance ete to police and other public officers were tried by the markaz courts, This accounts for a decrease from 26,556 misdemeanours in 1905 to 22,147 in 1906 tried by the summary tribunals. The jurisdiction of the summary tribunals in cases of contravention is very limited, the number in 1906 being 10,636, of which 92 resulted in convictions. The proportion of convictions by default against which opposition was made was 50% in misdemeanours and 28% in contraven- tions, but only in 17% and 10% respectively was the opposition snceessful. Sir Malcolm McIl- wraith also remarks “The whole procedure of default and opposition requires revision, and probably, of certain conditions, abrogation.” In misdemeanours: 23 % of the convictions re- sulted in. fies, 74% in imprisonment, and 3% in whipping er reformatory confinement, whiéreas in contraventions nearly all the con- victions resulted in fines.
CENTRAL TRIBUNALS.

15,964 misdemeanour and 1,652 contravention cases were tried on appeal in these tribunals. The propertion of reversals of sentences to fines to those to imprisonment was high and the Adviser considers that this suggest a doubt whether, when judges sentence to fine, they feel as sure of the guilt of the accused as whien they sentence to imprisonment. The proportion of reversals is not unreasonably high but the number of amendments of sentences shows a serious divergence of views in apportioning the sentence between the judges of first instance and those of appeal, especially in sentences to imprisonment. This divergence is most noticeable in the case of markaz misdemeanour sentences to imprison- ment, in which the proportion of amendments is neatly 50 7%. The only explanation of this which the Adviser can suggest is that in the markazes : the judges are able to obtain more precise information concerning the prisoners than is available for the appeal tribunals.
ASSIZE COURTS.

Of the 1,797 cases tried by the assize courts in 1906, 317 resulted in total or partial acquittals, 1,188 in convictions, 287 were declared misdeameanours or contraventions, in 4cases the courts declared themselves incom- petent, and 9 cases were adjourned. The proportion of cases acquitted to those tried was 17%, which can be considered reasonable, as it mast be remembered that the committing magistrates have only to consider whether there is sufficient evidence to justify the sending of the accused for trial, and not to establish guilt or innocence.
COURT OF APPEAL.

The number of cases of crime tried by the court of appeal during 1906 was 108, of which 25 were brought over from 1905 ; only 1 case was brought over from 1906 to this year. Certain categories of contravention cases (such as tanzim offences) are still tried on appeal by this court. Of the 1,002 cases to be disposed of 949 were dealt with, leaving 53 on. the cause list at the end of the year.

div.head: SHEM EL-NESSIM.
CHANCES OF DISORDERS.
div.p: As Shem el-Nessim draws near the rumours of some terrible catastrophe, which is to burst out on that day in Alexandria, grow in magni- tude and horror. As far as can be discovered these ramours do not repose on any-foundation in fact, but are mere bogies of a terror stricken imagination. 'The authorities of the Alexandria Gouvernorat consider that the attitade of the native population at the present time ia very quiet and by no means contains any inflamm- able ingredients tor an outbreak against Buro- peans. At the same time the Alexandria City Police will take all due measures to ensure the a passing off tranquilly by increasing, the police patrols and other measures, day is pale exceptionally tranquil in city as everybody makos it a rule to go out picnicking in the suburbs. The only danger is the extra. ordinary nervous tension prevailing, which will undoubtedly a large number of people in a very vanity state until the holiday has passed by. We have been continually receiving letters of late from correspondenta on the subjoct of the impending catastrophe One correspondent remarks :—

“Many local newspapers qualify the rumours prevailing both at Cairo and Alexandria aa to probable serious disorders on Shem el-Nessim day as ridioulous and keep reminding the public that the authorities are watchful. As far as I remember we had the pleasure of hearing a very samme assurance before the outbreak of the “Hamamil” affray some time ago, or the affair in the Square a year ago last December. A manifesto from the Gouvernorat stating that the first man to cause or stir up trouble will be liable to the severest punishment will no doubt help to quiet the public.”

It may be remarked in answer to our correspondent that in both the instances he cites the affrays arose out of simple incidents, which gave the troubles a serious air, because popular feeling was worked up then as it is now, to such astate of tension that the slightest pro- vocation necessarily led to a riot.

It is, however, noteworthy that while the police authorities declare that the attitude of the natives is tranquil, there are numbers of Europeans who state that they have had oral testimony to the contrary and that the attitude of the lowerclass native is very menacing and that many openly give vent to the most truculent sentiments.

Yesterday a Greek was set upon by a number of natives in Ragheb Pasha-street, Alexandria. It is reported that they declared to him that they would kill the Europeans on Shem-el-Nessim. The Greek was rescued from their clutches by a shawish, who, however, allowed the natives to escape.

On Monday evening the niece of a well- known official of the Ministry of Finance, who was on her way to her uncle's house at Shoubra, was followed by a Berberin, who remarked that she should take advantage of the 24 hours which remained to her as on the following day all foreigners would be massacred, and then made disgraceful proposals to her and even put his hands upon her. Shawishes were conspicuous by their absence and the young lady was pestered by the Berberin from the bridge to the house.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Henry Leshe Huntington, who was staying recently at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, succumbed last week to an operation under an anaesthetic. He only returned to London from Egypt on the 15th ult.
Mr. and Mrs. Hewat and family left Alex- andria yesterday by the S.S. City of Chios for Liverpool. Lady Cromer will no longer be “At Home” on Saturday afternoons.

div.head: MERSA MATROUH.
PROGRESS AND DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: The Egyptian Government has of late been trying to develop Mersa Matrouh. For the last few years special facilities have been giv to settlers and small grants of land, at about the rate of fonr feddans for each colonist, ha been made. There are about eighty European men, women, and children now settled ther of Italian and Greek nationality With the exception of the officials of the coastguards and police the other natives are Bedouin, the fellahoon will not settle there. The Ministry of Finance has given a grant to aid the colonists in the erection of buildings on the land given to them The Italians are masons and carpenters ; the Greeks trade with the Bedouin and the people from Siwa. They also have some bakkal shops and make a little money. by obtaining iron from the various wrecks along the coast It wav thought that the Grook sponge fishors would be induced to sotto at Meraa Matrouh, but up to now they have refused to do so.
THE SPONGE FISHERY

The sponges of the wostern coastline of Egypt are supposed to be the finest in the world not only for their quality but also for their beautiful symmetry. The sponge fishers come in schooners from the Turkish islands in the Archipelago. Each schooner brings from eight to ten boats and each of these boats are manned by eight men The boats pay a tax to the Egyptian Government of LE. 4 per year, It is estimated that about one thousand Greeks are engaged there for the six summer months in sponge fishing, and that the fishers net as the proceeds from the sponge harvest at least L.E. 20,000 annually. The fishermen are exclusively Greeks from Syme, Limassol, and Calymos, very few coming from Crete. The season begins in May and ends in the middle of October and during three months the fisher- men work all along the coastbetween Agami and Solloum. They return home and prepare their sponges on their islands and they are then sent to London, which is the central sponge marxet in the world. It is somewhat curious that it should be more difficult to get sponges at Mersa Matrouh than anywhere else in the world, but this is explained by the fact that before the fishermen leave their island homes they have a farewell service in their churches, where they swear that they will not dispose of a single Sponge until they return home. The reason for this oath is that their outfit is advanced by local capitalists to whom they are financially and morally bound to give all the proceeds of their fisheries. The sponge fishers are very industrious and bear high characters with the local authorities, to whom they give no trouble. They are a fine, handsome, primitive race of Greek islanders and are very pious ; they never do any work on Sundays or their numerous Saints days. They do not bring any, women with them and never settle at Mersa Matrouh, always preferring toreturn home The Government has made a breakwater at Mersa Matrouh so that the sponge fishers crafts protected against any weather. The idea of the breakwater was to induce them to their boats in the harbour during the winter, but they cannot be induced to stop.

The Government has prohibited the use of diving suits as the divers tore up the young plants and were continually meet- ing with fatal accidens owing to their out- of-date diving equipment. A vast number of fatalities have occurred owing to this reason and all along the coast nu- merous tombs of the Greek divers line the shore. At Sheila Rocks, thirty miles west of Mersa Matrouh, a large nomber of Greeks are buried and at all the rocky points on the coast: their tombs are to be fourid. They died from paralysis owing to the change of pressure. Now this dangerous use of the diving dress is forbid- den under the penalty of a severe fine and the comfiscation of their gear. Their operations are now confined to diving naked, They dive with a heavy piece of marble in their hands to take them far down into the depths of the sea, and go to extraordinary depths, twenty five fathoms and more. They have a piece of rope in their hands ard as soon as they have gathered enough sponges and their air anpply is becom- ing exhausted, they pull the rope and are hauled up by two men. Their agility is won- derful. Often they come up bleeding from the nose and ears. Every man prays and make the sign of the cross before diving. Apoplexy often carries them off. After this dangerous and work during their six months on the islands. There is a great future before the Egyptian sponge industry owing to the Government having put a stop to the use of diving suits and the consequent destruction of the young sponges. In a few years time the effect of this wise regulation will be visible in an increasing supply of sponges.
THE WATER SUPPLY

The future of the agricultural development of Mersa Matrouh defends entirely on the question of the water supply. In the times of the Ptolemies there was a town here known as Parostomium. From the ruins it is evident that the inhabitants kept their water in cisterns and the supply was evidently due to the rains. There are no traces of springs of freshwater in the neighbourhood. In antiquity elaborate pains were taken to make use of the rain water and along the road to the Siwa Oasis there are enourmous cisterns, about forty metres in diameter and fifty metres in length at Abou Haran and Abou Bouttah, which when filled by showers would have given a water supply for the whole year. The expense of hewing such enormous cisterns out of the rock is now out of the question and all attempts to obtain water are concentrated in sinking artesian wells. Recently the Egyptian Government charged the Artesian Boring and Prospecting Company with the istallation of an artesian well there The direction has been entrusted to Mr. Arthur Gaertner who is now engaged in boring operations. The first attempt was made about six kilometres south of Mersa Matrouh harbour and a depth of one hundred metres was obtained b t with no result In consequence the Government asked Mr. Tedeschi, the Manager of the Company, to make further trials to a depth of two hundred metres.

The implements of this boring have recent- ly arrived and work will begin at once. At the depth of from 81 to 100 metres the boring proceeds through a strata of hard blue clay. It is expected that a layer of limestone will suc- ceed the clay and here water may be found. It is of course possible that the water will be salty here, but when the bore proceeds to a depth of two hundred metres or even less the . water-bearing grey Nubian sandstone may bo arrived at: If water is not found the company intend to continue boring at their own expense to a depth of three hundred metres. At such a deep level all further operations will be abandoned and the future development of Marsa Matrouh will be very dubious. The existing water supply is obtained by digging small in the ground until the infiltration of the winter rains is reached. Such a supply is extremely limited and only just suffices for the wants of the few inhabitants.
PETROLEUM BORING

The Artesian Boring and Prospecting Company have engaged the services of a German boring spedialist, Herr Otto Dessau. He has had considerable experience in the Dutch Indies and British India in boring for petro- leum. He is of opinion from his experience in boring for water at Mersa Matrouh that the lay of the strata gives signs of petroleum. Two wells have already been sunk on behalf of the Company in order to discover if traces of petroleum can be found. Other wells will be sunk afterwards.
CONCLUSION.

Great hopes are entertained of the Khedive's. railway, which, it is expected, will reach Mersa Matrouh in the course of next year. The export of barley, wool, and quails will receive consi- derable development by means of the railway to Alexandria. If water can be found, and assisted by direct railway communication, Mersa Matrouh would then become a splendid barley producing centre as the land is specially adapted for barley. Its future depends solely on the water supply and until that is found the development of Egypt’s only harbour west of Alexandria will be highly problematical.

div.head: MILLE DUBOIS’ CONCERT.
div.p: On Tuesday night Mlle Marie Dubois gave a concert in the ball-room of the New Khe- divial Hotel assisted by her pupils. As was to be expected, the first item on the programme did not commence unfil a quarter of an hour after the time fixed for the concert. We are, however, used to these unnecessary delays at concerts in this town ; we are also used to interruptions at these concerts from late- comers and from those who delight to chatter throughout the performances, and of these annoyances there was no lack last night.

The programme opened with a ladies’chorus, Rubinstein’s “La Nuit” being chosen This was very effectively given by eight of Mile Dubois’ pupils, the altos being especially noticeable. The duet which followed was from Massenet’s “Mais,” Mme Eeman and and Mr. H. Girard giving a satisfactory account of them- selves. It is a great pity that M. Girard’s undoubtedly fine voice should be nearly ruined by an exaggerated tremolo, but his singing was clearly much appreciated by lovers of that school. Mille de Pitner charmed her hearers by her rendering of a pretty song of Chaminade’s, “Novembre.” Her voice though small is very true and pleasing and showed signs of careful training. It is a pity she was so very nervous as it was evident that she did not give us of her best. A violincello solo by M. Capusian was daintily executed, bat lacked life and was expressionless. Mme Arab evidently gave her audience pleasure by her singing of the well-known air from Gounod’s “Romeo et Juliette.” She, too, appeared to be suffering from the prevailing nervousness which was not unnatural, for to sing before a large audience in a large concert-room is a trying orderal for untried singers. Madame Alexakis brought the first part of the programme to an end by a very creditable performance of the “Grand air d'Asrael” by Franchetti. She has the finest voice of those of Mille Dubois’ pupils who were taking part last night, and will doubtless improve when she gets a proper bridge to her voice which is at present lacking. wise regulation will be visible in an increasing fam She ought not to attempt songs too high for her; some of her low notes were certainly very fine The second part opened with the famous "Ave Maria" from Massenet's Mais which was sung by Mme. Eeman with much greater success than before. We are of opinion that the violin obligato might well have been ommitted ; the beautiful music was not heard to advantage last night, the violonist being often out of tune and seldom troubling to keep with the singer.

Mr. Girard, Mlle de Pitner and Mme. Alexakis repeated their former successes. Mr. Girard's rendering of "Griselidis" was very fine, though unfortunately at times his "tremulo" was so great that it was difficult to say on which note he was singing. Mme. Alexakis' piano-playing was much appreciated her own competition being tuneful but not very original. We must not forget to mention the men's chorus which distinguished itself by its spirited rendering of Hahn's Pastorale and Rondel. In a word, the concert was a very fair success and reflected credit on Mlle. Dubois' capable teaching.

div.head: THE NATIONAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: LORD CROMER’S DESPATCH. London, May 1.

A Parliamentary paper has been issued con taining a despatch from Lord Cromer dated 8th March. Reviewing the proposal of the Egyptian National Assembly he says : ““With- out discussing whether all the members of the Assembly fully understood what is inyolv- ed in the term—granting a Constitution— I need only refer to the remark in my last report, I think it altogether premature to take any very decisive or rapid steps in the direc- tion of the introduction of full parliamentary institutions,” As regards provincial councils, he repeats that he favours reorganisation and some increase in their powers. An extension of the powers of the legislative council is much more difficult. He altogether opposed the vest- ing in the council of an absolute veto of government proposals. He considers the teaching of the sciences in Arabic at present. quite impossible, but something may be done in this direction in primary schools. He concludes by referring to the noteworthy fact that a large body of the Assembly is animated by very friendly feeling towards the present regime (Reuter)

div.head: THE EUROPEAN SITUATION
PRINCE VON BUELOW’S SPEECH.
div.p: Berlin, May 1, The Reichstag was crowded in expectation of the speech which Prince Von Buelow was expected to deliver on the European situation. Prince Von Buelow announced that Germany would not participate in the discussion of the limitation of armaments at the Hague Confer- evice, on the ground that it was dangerous and unlikely to lead to practical results, He depre- eated the nervous Press comments on the subject of the conclusion of ententes supposed to he hostile to Germany, declaring that the meeting between King Edward and King Victor Emmanuel. was perfectly natural. The frienfiship of England and Ital} is not merely compatible with the Triple Alliance, but useful and desirable. He regarded the prospect of an Anglo-Russian rapprochement without anxiety. Referring to the case of France and Morocco, he anticipated the gradual disappearance of mistrust. He gladly noted that at present no contentious questions were at issue between England and Germany. He emphasized that Germany always acted on the principle of securing peace by her readiness for war, but never abused, and would not abuse her strength, He was perfectly aware of the diffi- culties and dangers of Germany's geographical position but the best way for overcoming it was to concentrate her strengtli and be prepar- ed unitedly to defend peace and the honour of the country. (Reuter)

BERLIN, April 30, In his speech at the Reichstag Prince von Bulow justified the refusal of Germany to par- ticipate in the discussion of limitation of arma- ments at the Hague Conference, but it will consider any practical suggestion favouring peace. The Chancellor estimates that the Anglo- Italian friendship is compatible with the con- tinuation of Italy in the Triplice. He says that Germany seeks in Morocco economic equality and he hopes ameliorated relations with France. The relations with England are good. ( Havas)

Berlin, April 30, The discussion in the Reichstag on foreign politics was very dignified and calm. Prince von Bulow’s speech was greatly applauded Members of all parties spoke in a very pacific manner. ( Reuter)

div.head: THE PERSIAN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: TEHERAN, May 1 Parliament has, almost unanimously, voted the dismissal of the Minister of the Interior and has decided to demand the dismissal of the Foreign Minister unless he gives certain information which has been requested of him. ( Reuter )

div.head: GERMAN CHANCELLORS STATEMENTS.
LONDON PRESS APPROVAL.
div.p: London, May 1. The papers pay tribute to the moderation, wisdom, and straight-forwardness of Prince von Bulow’s statements and recognise the justice of his disarmament arguments from a German standpoint. Almost every country must be the guardian of its own interests. The "Morning Post" urges an immediate reconsideration of the British schemes for military and naval reductions as an answer to Prince von Bulow's announcement (Reuter)

div.head: GERMANY AND AUSTRIA.
div.p: Vienna, May 1. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has proceeded to Berlin to confer with Prince von Bulow on the international situation. (Reuter)

div.head: KING EDWARD'S TOUR
div.p: Paris, May 1. King Edward has arrived and will stay for He will see M. Fallieres to- morrow. (Reuter)
Paris, May 1. King Edward has arrived. (Havas)

div.head: EMPEROR OF GERMANY
div.p: CORFU, May 1. Emperor William has bought the Empress of Austria's villa, l’Achilleion. (H.)
BERLIN, May 1. Emperor William received Baron d'Aeren- thal. (Havas)

div.head: KING LEOPOLD IN PARIS.
div.p: Paris, May 1. The King of the Belgians is paying an official visit, He lunched yesterday with M. Fallitres who referred to the sympathy of the Government and people of the Republic to- wards the King. ( Reuter)

div.head: ATTEMPT ON PRESIDENT CABRERA
div.p: SANTIAGO DE GUATEMALA, May 1. Conspirators exploded a landmine under the roadway as President Cabrera drove past, killing the horses of his carriage and wounding an officer. The President was uninjured. (R.)

div.head: DANGEROUS RUSSIAN IN PARIS.
div.p: PARIS, May 1. From the top of an omnibus, which was crossing the Place de la Republic, a Russian fired revolver shots at some soldiers, Two of the latter were struck, but not wounded, The crowd tried to lynch the Russian, who was arrested end protected by the police.( Havas)

div.head: MAYDAY IN PARIS.
div.p: Paris, May 1. May-Day throughout the country was gener- ally quiet despite the Jabour agitation here and elsewhere. 700 arrests were made here, mostly of persons refusing to move, or who were carrying arms or distributing anarchist pamphlets. A man on the top of an omnibus fired a revolver at the troops in the Place de la République, hitting two of them: he was nearly lynched. ( Reuter )
Paris, May 1. The day has passed comparatively quietly. The telegrams from the provinces and other countries notify quiet. (Havas)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA & RAMLEH RAILWAY COMPANY LTD.
div.p: The last director's report of this Company, shows a considerable increase in its traffic’s receipts, since last year.
On the 30th September 1906, the nett pro- fits have attained the sum of L.E. 27,207, whereas on the preceeding year they were only LE. 19,353, showing a surplus of L.E. 7,854.

The Alexandria and Ramleh Railway was founded in 1862, with an original capital of £83,500, divided into 8,350 shares of £10 each. In consequence of the engine-traction by electri- city, in 1902-1903, the above capital, was increased to £110,000 and 26,500 new shares of £1 each were created at a premium of £1.12. per share. This premium was passed to a special reserve account which figures on the last balance sheet as “Premiums received on new shares issued,” for the amount of L.E. 38,621. The original 8,350 shares of a nominal value of £10, were then divided into 10 shares of £1 each.

The actual board of Directors of the Company is composed of, Boghos Pasha Nubar, President, M. Jacques Lumbroso, Vice President, M.M. R. Abdy, J. Aghion, J. C..My Cornish. M. Poilay, Bey. J. R. Reeves, Michel Salvago.

The general meeting held on the 27th De- cember last, passed the accounts of the year 1905, 1906, which showed, as we have already said, L E. 27,207 nett profits, out of which L.E.22, 791 were paid to the shares as dividend, ie 4 shillings and 3 pence per share, LE. 500 bonus to the staff, L.E 4,000 having been devoted to a special reserve for the renewal of the Company’s material; and L E. 280/602 having been carried forward to the present year. All this shows how the company has ad- vanced its business, and the gradual increase in its-dividends, contrasting with the decline in its shares market prices is most encourag- ing, The following figures will be of interest :
In reviewing the director's report the follow- ing comparison between the two last years is of importance.
TRAFFIC ACCOUNT.

Entertaining of lines & machines,etc.L.E. 9613 Movement: etc. .... 9858 Electric power production ... ... 8001 Against, in 1904-1905...24920 increase... ... ... LE. 2552 GENERAL EXPENSES. Divers -expenses ... ... .... ... LE. 5687 Salaries aud indemnities. .... ... ,, 1809 Interest on, debentures, etc... ... ,, 2043 Against 1904-1905 ... ... ... , 8790 increase... ... ... LE. 749

The total increase of expenditure of about L.E 3,300 may be considered satisfactory, in respect of a higher increase in the receipts. In fact, the percentage of the expenses is reduced from 65,584 to 58,667.

We observe also, that there remains only £17,600 from the Company's debentures issue, ie £22,400 of this debt is redeemed up-to now. This latter sum may be considered, so to speak, as a reserve having been employed in the writing off of the unmonved part of the Company’s assets, the reimbursement having been effected by a yearly deduction of about £1,200 from the profits.
The several reserves of the Company on the 30th September last, may be classified as follows :

Premium receiver on new shares LE 38,621 Interests on the sale of San Stefano’s Casino, payable by yearly instalments... 28,053 Assistance Fund ... ... ..175 Ordinary Reserve ... ... .. 7,450 Balance of profits carried for- ward to 1906-1907... ... ..281 Reserve for renewal of the material... 4,000 Total... .. ... L.E 78,580

With regard to the increase of L.E. 6,105 which is observed in the “First establishment Expenditure” account, it has been caused by the extension of the railways from the Khe- divah Palace Station to Victoria College, and again, by the constraction of sucliae. line between San Stefano and the Khedivah Palace.

div.head: NEW TYPEWRITING RECORD.
4,800 WORDS AN HOUR.
div.p: The world’s record in rapid typewriting as broken in London on the 11th ult by a oung man from Newcastle-on Tyne, who ccomplished the astonishing feat of type- writing 2,500 words from dictation in thirty inutes, and of copying from typewritten "manuscript" 4,800 words in one hour. The half-hour’s typewriting from dictation as done at the rate of eighty-four words a minute, or eighty two words a minute not counting words in which letters were incorrectly typed. The hour test worked out af eighty words a minute counting all words written, and seventy- eight a minute deducting mistakes. Previously the best authentic record was that recently made by a young American typist, Miss Rose L. Fritz, who, at the Chicago Coliseum, wrote for half an hour at the rate of seventy-seven words a minute. | ingineer Champion. Mr James Wright, a typist in the employ- ment of the engineering firm of Messrs. Scott and Mountain, of Newcastle, is the record breaker. A year ago he wrote 30,096 words in seven hours from dictation. A few days ago the “Express” suggested to Mr. W. J. Richard- son, chairman of the Bar-Lock Typewriter Company, thatan attempt should be made to capture the typewriting record for England, nd Mr. Richardson invited Mr. Wright to. come to London and essay the task. His firm gave him three days leave for the purpose. Mr. Bernard de Bear, principal of Pitman’s Metropolitan College, - agreed to conduct. the trial, and at a room in Pitman’s School in Southampton-row, Mr. Wright wrote against time in the presence of Mr. de Bear, Mr. F. Heelis, secretary. of Pitman’s and pre- sident of the Incorporated Society of Shorthand Writers, Mr. Richardson; and an “Express” representative. Speed tests in America are frequent, and it is a common practice for the typist to write out a single sentence over and over again, and to reckon that a satisfactory trial. Mr. Wright undertook a much more difficult work. In both the half-hour dictation test and the hour’s copying, he type-wrote matter in which there was no repetition, and which he had never written before. Mr. de Bear choge for dictation Mr. Cham- berlain’s speech at Birmingham on May 15, 1903. The hour's copying test consisted of speeches made by the late Lord Russell of Killowen and Mr. Haldane at an Eigh'y Club meeting. If the test had been taken from the ordinary language of business, Mr. Wright would have made an even better record, for in taking several minutes dictation from Pitman’s “Com- mercial Correspondence,” he wrote at the rate of 100, 101, and 105 words a minute. He has written as many as 106 words in a minute in ordinary business. As a feat of endurance the hour’s copying was quite as wonderful as the half hour from dictation was as a test of pure speed. At the end Mr. Wright smiled, rubbed his arms, and said “I could have done better if there had not been so many long words” The heads of the Pitman establishment agreed that the record as it stood was quite beyond anything they had previously seen. The Bar-Lock Typewriter can be obtained from Whitehead, Morris and Co. ARMY AND NAVY (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT) London, April 18th, Major Vivian Henry, Royal Fusiliers, late commanding the Depdt at Hounslow, has been ordered to embark on the 24th May for Cairo, where he will take up the command of the Mounted Infantry in Egypt. Colonel J. J. Asser, the new Adjutant General of the Egyptian Army, in succession to Major General Henry, C.B., was formerly a regimental otticer of the Dofsetshire Regi- ment, from which he went on half pay last January on completing ten years in the Khedive’s service, His first Egyptian experi- ence was serving regimentally with the Dorests, and for a few months he was aide de camp to the then G.O.C. in 1892. In 1897, he joined the Egyptian Army, and saw his first active service up the Nile under Kitchener (men- tioned in despatches, Egyptian medal with clasp); and he was brigade major in Kitchener's avenging march to Khartoum, including the battles of the Atbara and Omdurman (men tioned twice in despatches, brevet majority, two clasps, British medal). The batteries of Royal Horse Artillery and Royal Field Artillery in India are to be all armed with the new 12 pounder and 18 poun- der quick-firing guns respectively before the close of the present financial year. Consider able progress was made in the work last year, but since the present administration came into power it slacked off a bit. Orders to the amount of £55,000 of naval ordnance have been delivered at Woolwich Royal Arsenal. Whilst no one begrudges Lord Kitchener his extension in the Indian Command, every- one who has the interest of the army at heart wished him elsewhere. It is strongly felt that his proper place is at the War Office, where he would have abundant scope for his well known powers of organisation, and had he been there it is safe to says that the ill starred scheme of Mr. Haldane would never have seen the light. It reflects no credit on those responsible at the War Office that they have bowed the knee to a mere civilian—a Philosopher, who whilst stating that he has done nothing without consulting his collea- gues has managed to get everything his own way. The proper sphere for “ K of K,” is the War Office, and the sooner he is there the better for the efficiency and prestige of the British Army. London, April 20th. Major Haig, King’s Own Scottish Borderers, on appointment to the 1st Battalion, at Cairo, will embark for Alexandria on the 18th prox Lieutenants C.B. Hore, and P. J. Hobhouse, 2nd Battalion Royal Warwick Regiment, have been selected for service with the King’s African Rifles, and the Somaliland Militia respectively. The War Office has ruled that all books written by officers on full pay must receive War Office sanction before publication, the Chief of the General Staft to be responsible for the sanctioning of any publication “All books” must therefore ingude novels and "short stories," but the books made by the average officer will hardly come under the notice of the Chief of the Staff. The Army Council has directed that the information relative to alterations in the subordinate Army Corps establishments, which has hitherto been rendered to the War Office annually only, is in future, to be reported monthly, that temporary labour employed is to be similarly brought to notice, month by month, so long as the employment is continued. After four and a half year’s service as seago- ing training ship for cadets the Isis, cruiser, has been paid off at Devonpont, under the superintendance of her Commanding Officer, Capt. C.F. Sowerby. The Blake and Blenheim are to be converted into mother ships for destroyers, The conversion is not yet completed, and, in the case of one vessel, not yet commenced. Owing to the reduction in armament, these cruisers will be reclasssified in the lists. Colonel CE. Commeline, R.E., comnanding the Depot Battalion, at Chatham, is mentioned as the likely successor to Colonel A. W. Roper, the commanding Royal Engineer in Egypt. Colonel Commeline is a distinguished sapper, who has had wonderful experience of his work in almost every part of the Empige, When a subaltern he took part in the Zulu War, 1879, and present at Ulundi where Cétew’s impayos rushed to their doom. He was prominently engaged in the first Transvaal, War of 1881, and was a participant in the stubborn defence of Pretoria, and in the attack on the "Red House." For his services in the Zulu War, he wears the medal with clasp, and he was mention- ed in despatches for his gallantry during the leaguer of Pretoria. By the close of the present summer, no fewer than thirty-five "Dreadnoughts" will have been completed, begun or ordered, but of these thirty-five only seven will fly the British flag The other twenty-eight belong to foreign powers, and this is the first time in the history of the British Navy that it has been so grievously outnumbered in the most powerful type of ship. The monster battleships building, completed, or to be laid down before the close

of the summer of 1907, are as follows;-— England- four Dreadnoughts, three Invincibles :—total seven, France-—six Dantons, total, six. Japan —four monster battleships, two monster cruisers, Total six. South American Republics —six (or possibly eight) Dreadnoughts, total six. United States—two Michigans, two Paci- ficators ; total four, All these ships have been taken in hand since January 1905, In the five years January 1900-—January 1905—the same group of Powers laid down or ordered forty seven first-class battleships, of which six- teen were British. Thus, in the. Dreadnought era the British proportion has enormously declined, In 1905-7 it is only 20% of the battleships of the Great Naval Powers—in 1900-4 it was 34%. Another point is very striking. In 1900-4 the British warships were on the whole more powerful and larger than those of rival nations, the sole exception being the, United States. But in 1905-7 many of the armoured battleships and armoured cruisers are larger and more powerful than the British ships, so that the numerical disadvantage is now accompanied by a disadvantage in quality of ships. The three German, two Japanese, and two United States ships will be larger than any vessel that the United Kingdom possesses. It is true that to the above total of British monster ships should be added two battleships which should be begun about January 1908, and possibly a third which may be commenced about March 1908. But even so, the British total will only be ten and will be still below the proportion of a few years ago.) Not only this, but for the first time in the history of the British navy the two- power standard in large armoured ships will have been abandoned. The two power standard as defined, by Mr, Balfour, in the House of Commons this year, is equality in numbers to the fleets of any two Powers, plus a margin of two per cent. As there are three different groups of two powers, each of which is build- ing two monster ships, this involves for Eng- land fourteen monster ships in reply. But when even those ships to be begun so late as March of next year are counted, England has only ten, and of the ten some may be whittled away by Parliament. Two facts emerge. The country is not maintaining its position rel- atively to the fleets of the other great Powers, and it has also surrendered the historic two- power standard first laid down by Fox 127 years ago. So says the “Daily Mail.”

div.head: SOCIETE ANONYME AGRICOLE ET INDUSTRIELLE D'EGYPTE.
div.p: L’Assemblée Générale de la Société Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte a eu lien Jeudi 26 courant, au Sidge Social au Caire. Elle a approuvé le Bilanvet les comptes de l’Exercice écoulé et a décidé la distribution de: Frs. 55 aux Actions de Capital (soit 11 p.%/)et Frs. 60 aux Parts de Dividende. Les bénéfices nets de l'Exercice se sont éle- vés a L.E. 143.734. sur lesquelles une somme de L.E. 7.186,695 a été portée a la Réserve statutaire et une autre de L.E, 50.550 a une réserve spéciale pour prévisions sur ventes et loyers- De plus, une somme de LE. 9,709,247 a été reportée a nouveau. Les réserves totales de la Société s’élevent aujourd’hui a LB. 147.000 en chiffres ronds, sans compter la plus value des terrains qu’elle posséde et qui est évaluée a LE. 790,000 environ. La situation de la Société est done des plus prospéres et promet, grace a la sage adminis- tration dont celle-ci est dotée, des résultats toujours croissants et avantageux. Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES Le Caire, Mardi 30 Avril 1907. Le taux de l'escompte Jibre a Londres est resté invarié hier a 3 1/4. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8 4 85 3/8. L’Unifiée s'est maintefue a 102 1/4, La Na- tional Bank a rétrogradé de 3/8.4 23 1/8, La Dairaa regagné 1/8 a 15 1/2. L'Agricole a perdu 18 a 8 1/2, de méme qua la Delta Light a 10 3,8. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a baissé de 4 francs a 720, tandis que la Banque d’A- thénes est remontée de 2 francs a 125. Ici, le marché des valeurs a présente un calme exceptionnel par suite du fait que la liquidation a été opérée dans la matinée, Aussi bien la corbeille a été presque déserte durant toute la séance. Il n'y en a pas moins eu sept transactions, qui ont porté sur fa Banque d@ Orient, les obligations Crédit Foncier, les Cotton Mills, les parts de fondateur Epargne Im litre et Allotment. Les réglements paraissent se faire sans diffi- -cultés et l'on s’attend généralement a ce que la position de place soit appelée a s’ameliorer aprés les fétes et la liquidation d’Alexandrie. Une petite maison de courtage de cette ville a du suspendre hier ses paiements; mais son passif est insignificant. On annonce de Londres la fondation d’une Société anonyme, Au capital de £ 150,000, sous la dénomination de “Cairo Palace Theatre Ltd. ” L'objet de la nouvelle Societe est de créer au Cairo un palais artistique sur les terrains occupés actuellement par le Hamman et les magasins adjacents, L’opéra et la comédie alterneront avec la féerie et autres spectacles, Ily sera également établi un restaurant pari- sien, ainsi-qu’un Cercle sur le modéle des Clubs les plus luxueux et les plus confortables de Londres. L’émisson aura lieu trés prochaifiément a Paris et a Londres, Parmi les membrés du conseil d’administration figurent lord Pigall, le comte Louis de Talleyrand-Péricord, MM. Frank Allen, Nicalas Sabbagli bey, etc. Le conseiller artistique de lentreprise est M. Gaston Calmette, directeur du “Figaro.” L’assemblée générale extraerdinaire de la Société des Tramways Electriques du Caire, tenue a Bruxelles le 19 April courant, a auto- risé le conseil d’administration a porter le capital social a 20 millions de francs par la création de 20,000 actions privilégiées nou- vellés de 500 francs chacune, a éméttre en une ou plusieurs fois aux époques qu’il jugéra les plus favorables. L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Port- Said Salt Association Ltd. a ététenue samedi passé au aiége social a Alexandrie. Les comptes et bilan de l'exercice écoulé orit été approuvés et conformément 4 la proposition du conseil d’administration, il a été décidé de payer un dividende de 5 % a partir du 15 Mai prochain. Le Caire, Mercredi ler Mai 1907, Le taux del’escompte libre a Londres est toujours a 3 1/4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté hier invarié a 85 3/8, de méme que |’Unifiée a 102 1/4. La National Bank a rattrapé a 23 1/2 les 3/8 qu'elle ayait perdus la veille, l'Agricole est demeurée inchangée a 8 1/2, ainsi que la Dara a 15 1/2 et la Delta Light a 10 3/8. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est reaté stationnaire a 720. La Banque d’Athénes a encore avancé de 1 france a 126. Ici, la confiance tend peu a peu a renaitre grace, d’une part, a l’aisance remarquable avec laquelle les réglements de la liquidation de fin de mois ont été faits au Caire, et d'autre part, la meilleure tenue des fonds tiens a Londres, ou la National Bank est remontée hier de 3/8. En troisieme lieu, la fermeté relative du coton surplace, jointe a la hausse des prix en Amérique est un facteur important dont il convient de tenir compte. Il reste Adoubler le cap de la liquidation d’Alexandrie, aprés les fétes de Pagquies ortho doxes, pour se fixér sur l’orientation que pren- dra le marché financier lorsque les mesures extraordinatres actuelles auront cessé d’étre en vigueur. On assure a ce propos que l'intention des Comités des Bourses au Cairer et d’Alexandrie est de rapporter, graduellement, ces mesures dés le mardi 7 Mai. Ainsi le marché serait

d'abord rendu libre pour les valeurs traitées a Londrés, puis pour celles qui sont négocides a Paris a Bruxelles et successivement, par series, pour les autres titres. En attendant, le nombre des operations pra- tiquees ce matin en corbeille a eté de onze ; elles ont porté sur la Banque d’Orient, l'Im- mobiliére, l'Union Fonciére, la Banque d’A- thénes, l'Epargne Immobiliére, les Markets, etc. * * * L’Association des courtiers en valeurs d’A- lexandrie a fait afficher hier en Bourse l’avis suivant: "Les paiemnts des differences résultant des compensations doivent étre effectués le mercredi ler Mai 1907. Toute agence qui n’aura pas payé ses différences dans la journée sera considérée comme défaillante. ” “ The Egyptian Gazette ” d'hier se fait,dans son bulletin financier, l’écho d’une rumeur suivant laquelle la National Bank of Egypt n’aurait pas l'intention de procéder, pour le moment, a la nouvelle émission d’actions, qui nécesssiterait, comme l’on sait, nee d'un million de livrés sterling. Il y a lieu de faite remarquer a ce propos que cette ¢mission ne saurait étre considérée comme iminédiste, car l’assemblée générale ex- traordinaire qui-doit voter l’augmentation du capital ne se tiendra que le 8 Mai courant, “ The Egyptian Gazette ” a du, assurénient, vouloir dire que l’émission pourrait bien étre ni voyée ena utomne si l’état du marché ne s’a- méliorait pas dans le cours de l’été. On annoncé de Londres la formation d’une nouvelle Sogiété anonyme pour l’Egypte, sous la dénomination fe “ The Central Eastern Bank ”, au capital de £ 400,500, représenté par 100,000 actions de £ 4 chacune et 10,000 parts de fondgteur a 1 shelling. L’objet de la Société est dé s’occuper de toutes affaires de banque en Egypte, a Londres et autres lieux. Parmi les promoteurs figurent MM. E.Green, P. Mesciaca bey, M. Neghib Chakour pacha, résidant au Caire, et B. H. Mikhail a Assiout. Carnet de l’actionnaire. Les actionnaires des Egyptian Markets Ltd. sont informés que le coupon No. 7 pour le divi- dende déclaré au taux de 4 % (moins l’income- tax) copstituant le dividende final pour l’exer- cice clos le 31 Décembre 1906, est payable, depuis le 30 Avril 1907, aux guichets de l'An- glo-Egyptian Bank a Londres, ainsi qu’au Caire et a Alexandrie, au cours du changé. GLASG0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.
N. SPATHIS, Agent.
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Tyrol.
div.p: (Weissenstein Castle 103 feet). First-class. Private Hotel, near Windisch-Matrei station, Lienz. ( Easily reached from Trieste or Venice. ) Bracing air. Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing. Photos and Prospectuses at "Egyptian Gazette” office, Cairo. 29218-30A-4-907

National Bank of Egypt AVIS AUX ACTIONNAIRES. L'Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire qui avait été convéqueé pour le 20 Avril n’ayant pas réuni le nombre d’actions voulu, Messieurs les Actionnaires de la National Bank sont con- voqués a nouveau en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire pour le Mercredi 8 Mai 1907, a cinq heures de l’apres midi, au siege social, au Caire: Danscatte seconde réunion les délibérations seront valablement prises, quel que soit le nom- bré des actions représentées ORDRE DU JOUR: Augmentation du Capital Social et modi- fi ation de l’article 10 des statuts. Tout actionnaige possédant au moins vingt actions a droit de prendre part a l’Assemblée a condition de déposer ses actions dans l’un des lieux ci-aprés désignés ou il lui sera déli- vré une carte d’admission. En Egypte, cinq jours au moins avant l’Assemblée, soit le 3 Mai au plus tard : Au siége social, au Caire ; a la succursale d’Alexandrie ; aux Agences de la Banque A Assiout, Assonan, Benha, Beni-Souet, Chebin- el-Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Keneh, Man- sourah’ Minieb, Louxor, Port-Said, Sohag, Tantah, Zsgezig et Mousky (Caire) et dans lea établizsements de Bar que suaivants da Caire et d’Alexandrie: AngleEgyptian Bank, Bank of Egypt, Banque d’Atbénes, Banque Impériale Ottomane, Banque d’Orient, Bangoe de Ba- lon'qne, Cassa di Seonto « di Risparmio, Comptoir National d’Escompte de Paria, Crédit Lyonnais, Dentsche Orientbank A.@., En Europe, au plus tard le 2 Mai: a Paris, et a Marseille aux bureaux de la Société Marseillaise”; en Italie dans les bu- reaux de la “Banca Commerciale Italians;” a Londres a l’Agence de la National Bank, 4 & 5. King William St. Le Gouverneur : F. T. ROWLATT. Le Caire, le 22 Avril 1907. 30088-6-4 BANK OF ABYSSINIA. Il est porté a la connaissance de M.M. les Actionnaires qu’ils pourront retirer, a partir du “ler Mai, aux Guichets de la National Bank of Egypt au Caire, les Titres Définitifs aux Porteur libérés de Ls. 1.5 0., en échange des Certificats Provisoires se trouvant en leur possession. Le Caire, le 29 Avril 1907. 30150-10-3 NOTICE. {ENINSULAR & ORIENTAL STEAM NAVIGATION COMPARY. Summer Rates 15th May to 15th September 1907. Between First Second. Port Said and London £14. £9. '' Marseilles 10. £7. '' Brindisi 7. These rates ate Nett and do not entitle to a rebate upon the returning fare. Commencing 28th May the departure from Port Said to Marseilles is intended to be on Tuesday afternoon, after the arrival of the 11 a.m. Cairo train. A Steam Tender will convey Passengers to the ship. For the express convenience of Residents returning, the “Caledonia,” 8,000 tons, will leave Marseilles on 20th September for Alex- andria only. 30135-14-5

United Hotels of Egypt Limited. Notice is hereby given that Provisional Certificates for both Ordinary and Deferred Shares of the above Company can now be obtained at the office of the Local Secretary, Maison Chawarbi Pasha, Rue Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, in exchange for Allotment Letters and Bankers receipts for amounts paid on Appli- cation and Allotment. Shareholders are hereby informed that from the seventh day of April, 1907, interest at the rate of 9% per annum will be charged on all monies due in respect of Shares in the above Company. By Order of the Board, N. Morrison, 30142-3*-2 Local Secretary. Societe Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte. Municipalite d’Alexandrie AVIS Il est porté a la connaissance du public, que conformément aux avis paru dans les journaux, tout candidat au poste d’Ingénieur ou Dessinateur devra joindre a sa demande : 1°) Un certificat de naissance ou tout docu- ment en tenant lieu, 2°) Un certificat de bonne conduite. 3°) Tout certificat ou documents établissant son aptitude. Toute demande non accompagnee de ces piéces ne sera pas prise en considération lors du concours. Alexandrie le 23 Avril 1907, L‘Administrateur, 30117-3-3 (Signé) W.P. Il contient a completes et impartisles da coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der- nieres statistiques jusqu’a la veilie de sa publi- cation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc L'abonnement pour une annee en Egypte coute 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'etranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
